title: NORTH CLAY SCHOOL DRILL
full_story:
1/5/26
The North Clay School District in conjunction with the Clay County Sheriff’s Department will be conducting a law enforcement drill this afternoon.
Staff will be present, but students don’t return to the classrooms until tomorrow.  School law enforcement drills are a standard part of school safety protocols, mandated by state law to prepare staff for emergency situations.  These drills are designed to ensure familiarity with procedures and reduce panic during a real incident.
Today’s activity around the North Clay Schools is only a drill.

title: ATHLETIC HALL OF FLAME
full_story:
1/5/26
Flora High School has announced this year’s inductees into the Athletic Hall of Fame.
This year’s inductees are 1990 graduate and basketball player Curtis Leib, 1988 graduate, inducted for Track Joann Herring.  Baseball star and 1954 graduate Ron Ayers, 2016 graduate and basketball standout Crimson Jones.  From the class of 1976 for football Charlie Krutsinger, 1987 graduate and basketball standout Janet Krutsinger.  Football and Basketball star and 1947 graduate Melvin Dold, Wolves football coach for 1927, 28 and 57 and 58 Bert Dancey, WNOI Wolves and Wolfgals radio broadcaster Kenny Windle will get the service award.  1957 graduate Janice Hardy will be given the lifetime achievement award, and the 1984 Flora Wolves Basketball Team.
They will be inducted during Homecoming Weekend which is Saturday, September 26
th
.

title: CHRISTMAS TREE RECYCLING
full_story:
1/5/26
Today is the last day to drop off your live Christmas tree for recycling at the Clay County Health Department.  This is the 18
th
Annual Christmas Tree Collection.
Traditional, real Christmas trees can still serve a valuable purpose after the holiday season.  Because they are biodegradable, these trees can be used for environmental applications such as providing valuable habitats for fish in ponds and lakes or being turned into compost or mulch for erosion control and soil stabilization.
This year, any donated trees will be given to the Stephen A. Forbes State Park, where they will be used in the lake to provide cover and nutrients for fish.
Christmas trees may be dropped off at the West end of the Clay County Health Department any time before today by the Christmas Tree Collection sign and orange fencing.  Remember to remove any ornaments, decorations, and tinsel from your tree before dropping it off, these items are not biodegradable and will cause harm to wildlife.  A good rule of thumb is to take your tree to the drop-off location in the same condition as you would find it naturally in the forest.
If you have any questions or would like additional information, please contact the Clay County Health Department at 618-662-4406.
